awd_titl_txt: Mathematical and Computational Studies on Bose-Einstein Superfluid
awd_abstract_narration:
Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC), predicted by S. Bose and A. Einstein in the early 1920s, is a state of matter near absolute zero temperature for which all atoms lose their individual properties and condense into a macroscopic coherent 'super-wave'. Since its first experimental realization in 1995 (2001 Nobel Prize in Physics awarded to E. A. Cornell, W. Ketterle, and C. E. Wieman), BEC has been the focus of active research both experimentally and theoretically. It not only provides a new platform to investigate quantum properties of matter but also opens new perspectives for understanding the phenomena of superconductivity and superfluidity. The recent launch of the Cold Atom Laboratory to the space station on May 21, 2018 has once again drawn the spotlight to BEC superfluidity. This project focuses on the fundamental mathematical and computational issues arising in the study of Bose-Einstein superfluids to understand its behavior under the influence of artificial gauge fields and long-range dispersive interactions. It could potentially benefit the development of advanced technologies, for instance, superconducting quantum interference devices and atom interferometer-based sensors. 

The main objectives of this research are to build mathematical and computational treatments for the magnetic Schrodinger equations, to promote the understanding of Bose-Einstein superfluidity, so as to advance the experiments and applications of BEC. This project proposes systematic research on the mathematical modeling and numerical simulations of BEC superfluids in the presence of long-range dispersion interactions. On one hand, new mathematical and numerical issues introduced by the long-range dispersion will be investigated in detail. First, effective absorbing boundary conditions will be developed to avoid the artificial reflections of waves at the computational boundary, one persistent problem in wave simulations. Then accurate and efficient numerical methods will be designed to discretize the magnetic Schrodinger models. On the other hand, the solution properties of BEC will be studied analytically and numerically to understand the influence of long-range dispersion interaction and its interplay with nonlinear interactions. Both stability analysis and numerical simulations will be carried out to study the modulation instability and wave collapse due to the competition of dispersion and nonlinear interactions. Moreover, the properties of quantized vortices in the presence of artificial gauge field and nonlocal dispersive and/or nonlinear interactions will be investigated, so as to advance the understanding of BEC superfluidity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC), predicted by S. Bose and A. Einstein in the early 1920s, is a state of matter near absolute zero temperature for which all atoms lose their individual properties and condense into a macroscopic coherent super-wave. Since its first experimental realization in 1995 (2001 Nobel Prize in Physics awarded to E. Cornell, C. Wieman, and W. Ketterle), BEC has been the focus of active research, both experimentally and theoretically. It not only provides a new tool to investigate quantum properties of matter but also opens new perspectives for understanding the phenomena of superconductivity and superfluidity. The recent launch of the Cold Atom Laboratory to the space station has once again drawn spotlights to BEC superfluidity. The nucleation of quantized vortices in rotating BEC is the signature of superfluidity. In the last two decades, there have been tremendous studies on the quantized vortices and the superfluidity of BEC. With the experimental creation of dipolar condensates, more attention has been focusing on the nonlocal effects in BEC superfluidity. 

This project addresses fundamental mathematical and computational issues in the study of Bose-Einstein superfluids with focus on the long-range interactions. The main objectives of this research are to carry out mathematical and computational studies on the quantized vortices and to further the understanding of Bose-Einstein superfluidity. We investigate the new mathematical models and numerical issues introduced by the long-range dispersion.  Several accurate and efficient numerical methods, including finite difference methods, spectral methods, and meshfree methods, are developed to solve the nonlocal Schrodinger wave equation and its variations. The effective boundary conditions are studied, which could benefit the research of a broad community of nonlocal dispersive wave equations. The solution properties under the influence of long-range dispersion interaction and its interplay with nonlinear interactions are studied. Particularly, the properties quantized vortices are studied in the presence of artificial gauge field and nonlocal dispersive and/or nonlinear interactions.

Our studies could enhance the understanding of the superfluidity of Bose-Einstein condensation and potentially advance its applications. The numerical methods developed in this research will benefit the study and applications of nonlocal operators. The Schrodinger equations have wide applications in many fields, such as modeling Boson stars and dark matter, and thus our methods could provide effective numerical tools to study the phenomena in these fields. Our studies advance the understanding of long-range dispersion interactions. It could potentially provide new approaches to understand and control the properties of Bose-Einstein condensation and cold atom physics. Moreover, our results might provide physical insights for future experiments of BEC. 

This project enhances interdisciplinary research by bridging the gap between mathematics and quantum physics, and advance the understanding and applications of Bose-Einstein superfluids. Our studies could potentially benefit the development of advanced technologies. This award has supported three PhD students at the department of mathematic and statistics, Missouri University of Science and Technology, and one of them has graduated. The support from NSF has enhanced our PhD program and attracted more undergraduate and graduate students to pursue their degrees in computational and applied mathematics.
